Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Rigidity Theory for Multi-Robot Formations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal connects foundational research for multi-robot formations with the development of empowering experiences for women undergraduates in the classroom and beyond. The theoretical nature of the research is complemented by a firm grounding in hardware and computer vision fundamentals, integrated throughout a comprehensive education plan. The PI will develop an understanding of geometric formations of multi-robot systems, such as swarms in both 2- and 3-dimensions. Sensor and communication costs will be integral to modeling and algorithmic considerations, as minimizing power consumption is increasingly important for the design of lightweight and agile robot platforms. The PI will establish mathematical foundations and develop algorithms in three fundamental directions: (1) understanding a formation's structural properties, (2) producing optimal control architectures, and (3) predicting a formation?s internal motions. Developing a unifying theory from both theoretical and applied perspectives will produce a wealth of new directions, such as actuating a formation as if it were a single traditional robot.

The research contributions have the potential to significantly impact cutting-edge technology for the control and coordination of multi-robot systems. The PI is junior faculty at Mount Holyoke College, a liberal arts college for women, where a recent growth in enrollments has led to an average of 15 computer science majors a year (surpassing the peak of 2002). She will engage this vibrant community of budding computer scientists through her proposed education plan. Two courses will be developed, designed to simultaneously educate undergraduates through core computer science principles and expose them to exciting research problems challenging the field. Students will have additional opportunities for experiences outside the classroom through highly visible robotics and computer vision projects on campus, producing role models for generations to come. By working closely with the student-run CS Club, the PI will establish a supportive environment that fosters growing interest in technology from traditionally under-represented groups. She will also actively involve students in research by supervising two undergraduates each summer through a compelling research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Suppose you were given pasta and glue -- could you construct a car? What about wooden planks and bolts -- could you construct a footbridge? Now suppose you were given robotics parts (electronics components, microcontrollers) and a 3D printer -- could you build a group of robots that can carry a pizza? To do so, you would probably want a bit more training and experience in the computer science, mathematics and engineering fields that underlie robotics. For this funded project, we worked on two main components highlighted by this scenario: (1) producing computational and mathematical research results explicitly addressing the core research question of "collective transport," and (2) providing educational experiences to broaden participation in technology.

The problem of "collective transport" in robotics asks us to construct a formation of autonomous robots that can collaboratively move an object together. Applications range from multi-robot formations moving a delicate airplane wing during the manufacturing process to lifting rubble in a search and rescue mission. Just like an army of ants, a well-constructed formation of robots should be able to move objects much larger than any individual and adapt to a variety of situational constraints. We approached this question using three complementary perspectives: theoretical, simulated and real-world. We worked on the rigidity theory, which mathematically captures which local geometric properties lead to "rigid" formations (that collectively retain their shape) and developed algorithms to construct such formations. To evaluate our approach, we programmed individual robots in simulation to maintain specific distances to other robots, similar to a flock of geese, allowing us to control the entire formation via only the lead robots.  By implementing the approach in hardware, we were able to analyze the impact of the components used for sensing (e.g., a webcam for visual data versus an ultrasonic distance sensor) and identify real-world challenges to bring back to the theoretical domain. 

How do we attract, retain and support a broader population to work on problems like "collective transport" in the computer science, mathematics and engineering fields? Through this project, we were able to involve over 30 undergraduates from underrepresented groups in the research directly. These students worked on the algorithms, simulations and hardware implementations, with many inspired to subsequently pursue careers and advanced degrees in computer science. The associated image of a multi-robot formation carrying a net highlights the kind of work students were able to accomplish in a summer; a group of 6 built the formation from start to finish. More broadly, we were able to impact over a thousand students by supporting events organized by our student-run computer science club. These focused on constructing inclusive experiences for students with little or no tech background, with the goal of demystifying the field and highlighting its potential to have impact through creative and challenging problems.
